characters: EXT. TRANS-SIBERIAN RESTAURANT. TWO DAYS LATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's 5.30pm in late December and rain is pouring. The scant Christmas decorations are hanging limp in the rain. A young Turk (EKREM) runs through the rain with a Turkish newspaper held over his head. He ducks into a traditional barber's shop called Ozim's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shutters are drawn. OZIM (a plump middle-aged Turk) is cutting the hair of the last customer of the day (SOYK Soyka is a Chechen, well-groomed, wearing a sharp suit beneath the barber's gown. During the conversation we glimpse distinctive eagle- and star-shaped tattoos on Soyka's arms and hands. Ozim and Soyka are chatting as Ekrem enters.   Soyka spea with a Russian accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guvenilmez... daginik... bloody kids, you know... he says - `but Amca it's Christmas?... Christmas! We're Islam!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oi, how much are you taking off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christmas! So I said to him... alisverise cimac. The kid's sixteen... Ozim brushes some hair off the customer's shoulder and Ozim finally acknowledges Ekrem, who is shivering and wet near to the door. Ekrem turns the `Open' sign to `Closed'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't want to work do they. Shicma....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitantly interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Ozim....... We see for the first time that Ekrem is shaking with fear as well as cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision    -   9/12/06

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is him.     The kid I'm talking about. Ekrem approaches, stiffened by terror.       Soyka nods a in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks OK to me... how you doin' Ekrem? Soyka offers Ekrem a hand to shake and Ekrem stares at it as if it were enchanted...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks OK, yeah, but he won't do one lousy thing for me. Here, look... Ekrem, take this... Ozim takes an open razor from behind a line of hair-tonic bottles and hands it to Ekrem, who now looks mortally terrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ozim... memnum etmek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had a deal now he's backing out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Ozim, leave the kid alone. It's obviously a psychological thing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it Ekrem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ozim, it's OK. I don't want a shave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the kid who walks around like Al Capone. Take the fucking ustura and finish this Rushca.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (startled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLUE Revision    -   11/4/06

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Soyka rises up from the seat, casting off his barber's gown. Ozim yells `kabuka! And Ekrem snarls, flicks open the razor and drags it across Soyka's throat. Soyka's scr bubbles in the blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We dissolve to a Christmas decoration flashing on and off in the rain, high on a lamp post in Kilburn High Road. We pan down the lamp post to the High Road where revelers ar hurrying through the rain. We see a young girl (TATIANA) hurrying across the street, wrapped in a dressing gown with a man's overcoat thrown over the top of it. Her hair is soaked as she approaches an all night chemist's shop. She is barefoot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CHEMIST is delivering advice in Gujurati to a CUSTOME Tatiana wipes rain from her face and the Chemist and the customer react to her ragged appearance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Russian accent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please... I have...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For methadone I need to see paper prescription. The customer looks at Tatiana's feet and reacts. We see blood trickling down her legs. Tatiana looks down, then faints onto the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Tatiana unconscious on a wheeled trolley bursting through double doors into the operating ward of Trafalgar hospital. The trolley is accompanied by TWO NURSES, a JUNIOR DOCTOR and a midwife, (ANNA KHITROVA). The two PARAMEDICS who brought her are following behind the troll

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get a name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLUE Revision    -   11/4/06

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tiny brown handbag is being shaken empty by a nurse. Tatiana is being prepared for an emergency Caesarean. The theater is full of people in scrubs, including an anesthetist. Monitors and drips are being attached at dou speed. We notice that her arms are already dotted with festering needle marks. A nurse searches through the contents of the handbag and we can hear frantic activity from the operating table....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her stats are very poor, very poor. Baby's very distressed. Anna approaches the nurse, who is rummaging through the contents of the bag. We see a business card from a restaurant called `The Trans-Siberian', a St. Christopher necklace and a tiny battered diary. Anna grabs the diary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoulder distocia, I think.   Stuck on the pubic bone. Cut to Anna at Tatiana's head.    Anna strokes her face a speaks softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling... darling, can you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby's heart beat sixty... fifty- eight, fifty-eight... fifty-seven...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna, I'm trying to rotate the shoulder medially... shit... THE JUNIOR DOCTOR is breathing hard with a look of utter panic as he attempts to free the baby. The doors burst open and a more senior doctor in his mid thirties (DOCTOR AZIZ) enters at a gallop. As he enters..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision    -   9/12/06

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby stats sixty-eight and in free fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not getting a pulse. Heartbeats. Doctor Aziz joins the junior doctor, who look out of his depth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speak to me... Before the junior doctor can speak Anna speaks directly t Aziz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need to get the baby out now. Aziz knows he can take Anna's word...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, let's go. All hell is let loose. As the Caesarean process begins at frantic speed, we slowly zoom in on Tatiana's unconscious face and hear her voice in V.O... a young girl's voice speaking with an Russian accent. The crosstalk between nurses and doctors becomes more and more frantic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Tatiana. My father died in the mines in my village, so he was already buried when he died. We were all buried there. Buried under the soil of Russia. That is why I left to find a better life. We hear... a baby cry. Anna's face appears in our framed shot of Tatiana's face. She gently kisses Tatiana's cheek

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had a girl. A sheet is pulled over Tatiana's face. A nurse weighs the screaming baby. Anna wipes her brow with the back of her bloody wrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLUE Revision     -   11/4/06                           6

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ok.   Call it. The Junior doctor and a nurse check watches and speak alm in unison...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unidentified woman, died December 24th at 11.13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby girl, born December 24th at 11.14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna leaves the labor ward, putting on her crash helmet. She emerges out into the crisp, sunny morning. Aziz hurri to catch her up and hands her a wrapped gift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas, Anna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, don't be ridiculous. He grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you have to open it in front of me. Aziz smiles as Anna unwraps a pair of leather motorcyclin gloves. She looks up at him, expressionless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least pretend. Anna considers the gloves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deadpan))

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the whole entire history of my life, I have never felt this special.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PINK Revision       -    11/12/06

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Aziz plants a kiss on his two fingers and presses his fingers against Anna's cheek through the open visor of th helmet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wear them.       It's cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna rides her big vintage URAL motorcycle through desert morning streets. As she rides, we hear Tatiana in V.O.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am so excited this morning. Yesterday a friend came back to our village and he told us all about the places on the map that I look at... Paris, Amsterdam, London. He's been there for real...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After the bright airiness of the bike ride, we are sudden in Anna's bedroom where the curtains are drawn. Anna is lying awake on the bed, wearing a dressing gown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...he said the future of everything was already happening in all those places. There is a gentle knock at the door, which opens before Anna can respond. It is ANNA'S MOTHER (HELEN) with a cup of tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you sleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no point us tiptoeing around if you're not even sleeping. Helen puts the tea on the dressing table, then turns to leave without a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mum?       Are you OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PINK Revision    -   11/12/06

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (contrite) Of course not. It's Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna is pouring two glasses of sherry. Helen is peeling potatoes. Anna peers at Helen... and sees tears. They share a moment of stifled emotion. Helen wipes her eyes with her sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the chicken. (pause) The smell of chicken roasting reminds me of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should have done beef, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at each other and giggle. They both have potato peelers in their wet hands, sleeves rolled up, two practi unsentimental women being almost consumed by the same wav of emotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wouldn't be Christmas without tears in the gravy, would it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear a gruff Russian voice calling out from the living room (UNCLE STEPAN).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry) Anna! Anna!    Where did you get this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna and Helen roll their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) It's your own fault for giving him something to play with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritated) Well, I can't read Russian, can I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna drops her peeler and hurries into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PINK Revision    -   11/12/06

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The living room table is laid for dinner. Uncle Stepan is early seventies, Russian. He is reading the tiny diary that Anna found in Tatiana's bag. Anna breezes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you, Uncle Stepan, I found it in the handbag of a girl who died in my ward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you always rob the bodies of the dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suppressed, familiar anger) Of course, we all do it. It's one of the perks of working in a hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stepan grumbles, accustomed to this teasing. Helen enters carrying a bowl of walnuts and brazil nuts which she places on the table. Pause.   Stepan looks pointedly at Helen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know that your daughter robs the bodies of the dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PINK Revision    -   11/12/06

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stepan, is there an address?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stepan lays the diary aside, obstinate and prim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have an uncle who doesn't steal things from the dead. Not even their secrets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, don't go all momentous on us, Stepan. (she straightens the table cloth) Lift your elbows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should put this in her coffin, Anna. Bury her secrets with her bodies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Body.   Singular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stepan leaves in a huff. Anna picks up the diary and begi to study it. She sees the `Trans-Siberian' business card between the pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long will dinner be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen looks at Anna, suspecting an attempt to escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driving music as we see Anna riding her motorbike through deserted morning streets again. We should begin to sense that this is a kind of release for her. We hear Tatiana in V.O.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was little, London was like a place in the Bible. I wasn't even sure if it was real. My friend has told me there is a place in London where they pay girls to sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PINK Revision    -   11/12/06

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Anna arrives outside the `Trans-Siberian' restaurant. It has a Russian-themed frontage in blue and gold, expensive and recently finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said if I sang in this restaurant I would make more money in a week than my father made in a year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Anna pulls up we hear a dog begin to bark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The side door opens to reveal a hard-looking, handsome Russian man (NIKOLAI), who stops to groom his hair back from his face and put on a pair of sunglasses as he emerg into daylight. He steps into a small courtyard, where a fierce Doberman dog is barking and snarling on the end of a chain. Nikolai is followed by KIRILL, who is a little younger, slim and pretty but hard-looking too. Kirill is dressed i a crumpled T-shirt and jeans and looks like he had a heav night. Nikolai ignores the dog as he walks by but Kirill yells at it and teases it with a whoop and few Russian curses. Nikolai unbolts the gate to the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you pick up Ozim and his bitch of a wife and you bring them back here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances back at the restaurant and speaks softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I'll think of an excuse and we can get away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll think of an excuse. Your excuses are like fucking fairy tales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kirill grins and Nikolai flicks the fob of his car keys. The lights on an expensive black Mercedes glow in respons Kirill notices Anna locking up her bike at the front of the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the fuck's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PINK Revision    -     11/12/06

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They both see Anna removing her crash helmet and shaking out her hair. She walks towards the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Russian) Maybe somebody sent your dad a hooker for Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) You're so... fucking unbelievably disrespectful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kirill sees that Nikolai is studying Anna and his grin fades. We sense jealousy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you've got work to do.   Go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kirill grabs Nikolai's face to distract him, gives him a playful slap, but there is somehow more to it than playfulness. Nikolai gets into his car. Kirill glares at Anna as she approaches the front of the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Nikolai drives away, Anna rings the doorbell beside th front door. There is no reply. She is about to ring again when the door opens. We see SEMYON, a Russian man in his late sixties. He is wiping his hands on a tea towel, dressed in a spotlessly white apron. He has the sparkling piercing eyes of a falcon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She fumbles in her bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry... I'm a midwife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna produces her hospital ID and shows it to Semyon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLUE Revision    -   11/4/06

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a twinkle) Then unless one of my daughters is keeping something from me, you have the wrong address.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to speak to the Manager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Semyon studies the name on the ID.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Khitrova?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dad was Russian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Semyon seems suddenly delighted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And his name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ivan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you are Anna Ivanovna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tables are set for a huge party. Kirill is now on step ladders, fixing some Christmas decorations. Other relatives are getting the place ready. Semyon hurries through the restaurant, leading Anna by the hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must hurry. I must stir. Stir, stir or the gravy dies in my hands. Today it is family. Here is my son, Kirill. (he hisses at Kirill) Kirill! The berries are too low, too low. And Roman, more glasses for red! (he claps his hands) Come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kirill follows Anna's progress through the restaurant wit a glare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLUE Revision   -   11/4/06                           13A

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: There are three little girls in extravagant party frocks, all holding violins and giggling near to the door that

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLUE Revision    -   11/4/06

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: leads to the kitchen. Semyon stops when he reaches them and puts his hands on his hips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My angels. You should be practising. You must make the wood cry. Like this, like this... Semyon grabs a violin and plays a three-second burst of sad Russian violin music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see... Semyon hurries on into the kitchen.    Anna smiles, delig at the eccentric old man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the kitchen there is an inferno of activity, steam smoke. Family members, some dressed in their party outfit others in chefs' uniforms, are standing over steaming pot laughing, arguing. Children play and yell. You can almost smell Christmas. Anna enters, dazzled by it all, overwhelmed by the contrast to her own lifeless Christmas kitchen. Semyon calls out to everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, come, hurry, hurry.    They will be here any moment. (to Anna)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ok, show me this card. Anna reaches into her pocket and produces the `Trans- Siberian' business card she found in Tatiana's bag. Semyo angles his head to look as he stirs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the old card. From before the renovations. But even so, if she had worked here I would remember the name. Perhaps she ate here once. Try this. Semyon offers Anna a spoonful of his gravy.    She sips i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, that's amazing. My dad made gravy just like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PINK Revision    -   11/12/06

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Semyon shrugs and smiles, his eyes twinkling, then goes back to stirring. He speaks as if unconcerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So did you get a chance to talk to this girl before she died?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikolai's black Mercedes pulls up outside the restaurant and parks a few inches from Anna's motorbike. The rear windows are sun shaded so we only see Nikolai in the driver's seat.   He gets out of the car and opens the rea door of the car for an elegantly dressed Turkish lady in her fifties. Nikolai goes to the other rear door. The portly figure of Ozim the barber emerges. As Ozim gets ou he gives Nikolai a fifty-pound note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two of the little girl violinists are fighting, pulling each other's hair. The third is sobbing, sitting on the floor. A young woman in a party dress is carrying a huge silver bowl of sauce across the kitchen. Anna looks delighted at the noise and energy of the place Finally Semyon emerges from a cloud of steam with a scrap of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is an agency that hires casual kitchen staff. Maybe you will have more luck there. But I think they will be closed until New Year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Anna takes the address, Kirill puts his head around the door and yells through the noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papa, Ozim is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Semyon is alarmed and claps his hand in urgent fashion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten minutes!! (to the rest of the kitchen) Fish, fish, fish! Ten minutes! OK, Kirill, get him a drink and tell him I am coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision    -   9/12/06

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Semyon takes a pot from the heat, suddenly flustered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna, I'm so sorry I couldn't help. It is sad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's OK. I'll probably find out more when I get her diary translated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her diary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is the tiniest of changes in Semyon's manner. lays his heavy pot down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found her diary in her bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause. Semyon disappears into a billow of steam to put a pan onto the heat then re-emerges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you not tell me you found a diary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He peers at her for a moment, his eyes hardening a little

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, Anna, this is how it will be. You will bring the diary here and I will translate it for you. Then if we get the names of any relatives I will call them myself. I am something of a... community leader for the Russians here in this unfriendly city. What do you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Semyon hoists a passing child into his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was going to ask my uncle....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (apparently not hearing) And when you come I will make you some more gravy like your papa used to make and you can try the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLUE Revision    -   11/4/06

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: fish with the sauce. OK? Tomorrow, yes? Shall we say seven? Anna is a little overwhelmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it is settled. But for now, you must forgive me. Semyon shrugs then kisses Anna on both cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dosvedania. (Goodbye)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dosvedania. Anna heads for the door that leads back to the restaurant Semyon goes back to stirring but as he stirs he calls out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Anna, you always work at the Trafalgar hospital?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, always. A pause before Anna leaves Semyon to his clouds of steam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kirill and Ozim are talking confidentially in a mix of Russian and Turkish whispers at a table. Ozim's wife is at a table alone, well out of their earshot, smoking a cigarette and peeling glazed figs. As Anna walks by, Ozim and Kirill stop talking. The scene has a much darker mood to the bustling scene in the kitchen, but for now Anna feels no unease. As she passes, Kirill surveys her with a deadly smile and a professional eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you OK?     You want a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks.     I'm driving. As Anna smiles, Ozim mumbles something in Turkish and Kir shushes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PINK Revision      -   11/12/06

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK.     Merry Christmas.   Drive safely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ozim giggles.      Anna departs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna emerges into the daylight. As she does she sees that four expensive-looking cars have already parked and vario ostentatiously dressed Russian and Turkish couples with their children are emerging from their cars. The women ar all wearing furs, even the little girls. The men wear leather or dark suits. They greet each other exuberantly as they emerge from their cars. Anna suddenly feels slightly uneasy. As she approaches her motorbike she sees Nikolai leaning against the bonnet of his car, smoking, still wearing shades. His bumper is almost touching Anna' bike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Russian) Nice bike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice bike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Ural. You don't see them anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was my dad's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much do you want for it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna has already taken a dislike to this man. He is arrogant and looks potentially violent. His shades, suit and tattoos say it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritated) It has sentimental value.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikolai rolls the concept around in his mind and consider

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PINK Revision    -   11/12/06

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Sentimental value'.   I've heard of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna puts her helmet on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLUE Revision    -   11/4/06

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not staying for the party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nor me. Chauffeurs don't get invited. You want to go for a drink instead? Anna mounts her bike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Christmas. Everything's closed. Nikolai smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes if things are closed you just open them up, you know? Anna now feels intimidated and luckily the bike fires fir time. She rides away. Nikolai watches her go and then stubs his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sudden silence... perhaps the ticking of a clock. This is Anna's Christmas dinner, a total contrast to the chaos of the restaurant. Stepan is attempting to carve the chicken

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna, how come is it that your boyfriend isn't here to carve? Stepan takes a large sip of vodka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't live with Oliver any more, Uncle Stepan. I'm living back here for a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For as long as you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew he would run away from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLUE Revision    -   11/4/06

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't run away. You make me sound like a burning building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black men always run away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Stepan!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?   I am allowed to be honest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a doctor, Stepan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell has that got to do with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.     Stepan sips his vodka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not natural to mix race and race. That is why your baby died inside you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna slams her napkin onto the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stepan, shut up! (Anna gets to her feet) Please Anna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen takes Anna's hand but she turns and leaves. Helen stands to follow her, but first she whips Stepan's vodka away from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're just how he was. Stupid bloody drunken Russians.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The garden is just outside the kitchen. Anna is lighting a cigarette. Helen steps outside and reacts to the cigarette. She is about to admonish Anna for smoking, but Anna speaks first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision    -   9/12/06

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Christmas. I'm thirty-one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.     Anna blows smoke, clearly upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna, you know what he's like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't give a damn about Stepan. Who has that poor baby got in the whole world?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen reacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew this would happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Fine.     So you know everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna, she isn't your responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The baby is my responsibility until I hand her over to the mother. The mother is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it's up to the proper authorities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna smiles as if in agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The proper authorities will all be skiing until after New Year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna coughs a little then stubs her cigarette.        Hel the butt as if it were poisonous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's part of the grieving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What grieving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen touches her hand.      An inadequate gesture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GOLDENROD Revision   -   11/27/06                       2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the last year you've lost your father and you lost a baby. Anna is irritated but doesn't put words to her feelings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in and have your dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not hungry. Anna and Helen look into each other's eyes for a moment before Helen heads for the kitchen, carrying the cigarett butt as if it were a deadly snake.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: In a private room in the Special Care Baby Unit, Anna approaches Tatiana's baby's plastic crib. The baby is tightly bundled up, sound asleep. Through the windows of the room, we see the darkened, quiet ward outside - anoth world. Anna stands over the baby, her face full of emotion. Ther we see pain, loss, shame, emptiness, isolation. Tears beg to roll from her eyes, and then she is sobbing soundlessl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Trans-Siberian restaurant is smoky with cigarettes an cigars. The party is in full swing with two dozen guests and family. One of the golden-haired children is playing violin badly. The language is Russian, English and Turkis mixed. Kirill is bringing a huge baked carp to the table. His mobile phone rings and he wipes his hands on a towel to answer it. When he hears the voice, Kirill glances at his father and moves quickly out of earshot. Semyon notices but hides his concern. As Kirill walks, a child tugs his leg and holds up a soft toy, asking a question in Russian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to child)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's called Goofy... Goofy yeah. (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So the coast is clear, yeah? What? I said `coast'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GOLDENROD Revision    -   11/27/06

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) No, not the beach. It's an English expression, you fucking baboon. I mean... (hissing out of ear shot) ...there are no police. You sure? Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kirill glances over at Semyon, who is apparently lost amongst a sea of children, but we see from the corner of his eye he is watching Kirill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GREEN Revision   -   11/24/06

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, my dad's not involved. I'm a big boy now. I do my own stuff. Yeah. Merry Christmas. Kirill cuts the call and nods to Ozim, who stubs his ciga Semyon notices their silent communication, then turns to one of the violin-playing angels, smiles, and kisses her on both cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the car pull up sharply outside Ozim's barber's shop. Nikolai jumps out and opens the door for Ozim.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: The three men walk to the door beside the barber shop. Ozim takes a bunch of keys out and prepares to open the door to the upstairs. He stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver stays down here. Kirill smiles and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really think I do this kind of thing? Kirill puts his hand on Nikolai's shoulder

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy's not a driver. He's an undertaker. Ozim looks at Nikolai, highly dubious. BLUE Revision   -   11/4/06

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rooms above Ozim's shop have been converted into a drinking club. Ozim leads Nikolai and Kirill through the debris of the night before. As they walk through, Ekrem suddenly leaps out of the darkness with a yell. Kirill and Nikolai both react with instinctive aggression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, hey, hey Ekrem, sakim, durgun, durgun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got tickets, Ozim. It's with Chelsea. They said there was no tickets but I got tickets for the Chelsea game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, OK, OK.    You go and watch a DVD, yeah? Ekrem nods and hugs Ozim. We realize he is slightly deranged. Finally he lets Ozim go and leaves. Kirill watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows to say he hasn't seen us, right Ozim? Ozim finds the key to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He don't know anything.    He's touched by the angels. Ozim opens the kitchen door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the kitchen there are carcasses of lambs hanging from meat hooks. There are knives and skewers around the place. Ozim stops and locks the kitchen door behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The freezer door opens and Ozim gestures towards a large package bound up in black bin liners which are dusted wit frost. Kirill nods to Nikolai who grabs the package and hauls it out onto the kitchen floor. Kirill tears a hole in the bin liner and we see the frost-dusted face of Soyk

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLUE Revision     -   11/4/06

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Kirill studies the face and nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kirill crosses himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a time when he was like a brother to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts his hand on his heart with mock solemnity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now he looks like a fucking ice cream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kirill giggles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Hey, hey, show some respect for a dead man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Respect?   This is respect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kirill reaches into his pocket and produces an envelope which he hands to Ozim. As Ozim opens the envelope and begins to count the huge wad of cash, Kirill turns to Nikolai.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, Nikolai, he's all yours. And show some respect. This Muslim is scared of ghosts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikolai squeezes the body inside the bags.       It is ro hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you got a hair dryer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We cut close to an ancient-looking hair dryer from the shop downstairs being trained onto a human hand with a large eagle tattoo. We pull wide to reveal the full, gruesome scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision    -   9/12/06

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Nikolai has the body of Soyka laid out on a surface, his head still bound up in a bin bag, his lower portions boun up similarly. Nikolai is de-frosting Soyka's left hand with the hair dryer, concentrating on his ring finger whi has a gold ring on it. The parts of Soyka's shirt and jacket which are visible are crusted with frozen blood. Nikolai is wearing rubber gloves. As he dries, Nikolai takes a sip of coffee. Ozim is watching this scene with horror. Kirill has his arms folded, mightily impressed. Finally the hand is thawed enough for Nikolai to remove the gold ring. He studies an inscription and then offers it to Ozim. Ozim shakes his head as if the thing were a contagion. Nikolai shrugs and pockets it. He then turns the hair dryer back on and blows some hot air onto the crisply bloody chest of Soyka. He tugs at the frozen lape of the jacket and blows air into the inside pocket. Withi a few moments he is able to remove Soyka's glistening, thawing wallet which is caked in frozen blood. He opens it (we glimpse a photo of a wife and children) and blows hot air onto the money inside. He tugs a wad of frozen bank notes from the wallet, all stuck together by drops of frozen blood. He offers this money to Ozim as well but Ozim shakes his head vigorously Kirill hoots with laughter. Ozim is now staring at Nikola as if he were a devil from hell. Nikolai grabs a plastic bag and puts the money inside it, then pockets the frozen wad. He tosses the rest of the frozen wallet to Ozim, who instinctively catches it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd better burn that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ozim, reacting to the cold of the wallet and to the horro of it, drops the thing on the floor. Nikolai looks at Ozim as if he were a complete amateur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you finish cutting his hair?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ozim can't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just thought you might want six- fifty out of his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLUE Revision    -   11/4/06

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Kirill laughs.    Nikolai takes a deep breath to prepare himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, now I'm going to do his teeth and cut off his fingers. (to Ozim)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might want to leave the room. Ozim thinks, decides, leaves fast.   A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You too, Kirill. Kirill smiles and pats Nikolai on the cheek. Kirill leaves. Nikolai is left alone. His hand shakes a little as he picks up his cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikolai pulls up beside a rusting crane on the abandoned dock in a dry-cleaner's van. Kirill watches as Nikolai grabs the semi-thawed body, now bagged and tied, lifts it onto his shoulder, and smartly approaches the dockside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you going to weight him down or something? Nikolai drops the body into the water with a splash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want to dump a body, this is the place. The currents keep it under the surface until past the barrier. Nikolai and Kirill watch as the body is swallowed by a fast ocean-bound current.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna pulls up at some lights on her motorbike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friend said he would get me to Amsterdam and from there we could find a way into London. I have been practising my singing and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLUE Revision    -   11/4/06

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: have even rejoined the church choir. I am also practising my English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Semyon sits alone at the dinner table in the restaurant where before there was family and uproar. Outside it's dark and raining. He is reading a Russian crime novel. A half-empty bottle of vodka sits on the table. Tatiana's voice-over continues as we cut inside the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friend says his uncle owns the restaurant where you can sing. He is sure this man will take care of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a knock at the door and Semyon looks up sharply. His eyes glisten. He puts his novel aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Semyon is unlocking the door and discovering, in the driz and half light, that it is Anna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. My dear! I wasn't expecting you so early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Semyon and Anna are sitting down at the candlelit table. Anna fumbles in her bag and produces a sheaf of photocopi sheets. She has photocopied the pages of the diary and they are laid out in segments on each page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I copied the whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Semyon takes the pages and looks troubled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is the original?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision    -     9/12/06

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to keep it. Maybe give it to Tatiana's daughter someday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Semyon looks thwarted but hides it well. He studies the photocopied sheets for a while then looks up and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will need my spectacles and a clear head. Today I broke my rules and drank vodka. Tomorrow I will translate it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He folds the papers carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I will bring what I have done to your home. Where do you live, Anna?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is nothing in Semyon's smile to cause alarm but Ann perhaps remembers Nikolai. Finally...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not far.    I can drop by and pick it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then maybe I can drive you home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine.    I'm on my motorbike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Semyon stares at her for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what will happen to the poor child?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After Christmas, they'll do a missing persons report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who will?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PINK Revision    -   11/12/06                           3

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Semyon doesn't blink. At that moment a little girl of seven (MARIA) emerges from the darkness, carrying a soft toy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandpa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, hey, Maria, go back to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm too sad. Next Christmas isn't for another hundreds and hundreds of days. Semyon takes her onto his knee. As he does, we see, for the first time, an eagle tattoo on his wrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you have had so many presents. The girl wafts Semyon's cigar smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't smoke, Grandpa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Semyon cuddles Maria and stubs his cigar. Anna smiles at the warm family scene, perhaps remembering her own father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikolai gets out of the Mercedes and helps an extremely pissed Kirill out of the car into the rain. Kirill is so drunk he slips through Nikolai's hands and lands in the gutter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're partners now, man, you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLUE Revision    -   11/4/06

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikolai manages to lift him to his feet again. As they head towards the restaurant, Anna emerges. Nikolai looks up, curious, as Semyon kisses her on both cheeks in the doorway. As she turns Kirill stumbles forwards and collap in front of her. Nikolai looks up at Anna, his face splashed with rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? You never seen anybody pissed before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Semyon looks down at the drunken Kirill and slams the doo of the restaurant. Nikolai sighs, then turns to Kirill and starts to go through his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Kirill. Where are your keys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna walks around the two of them, watching the undignifi struggle as Nikolai finds Kirill's keys. Nikolai smiles at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna hurries away into the rain. Nikolai finds Kirill's keys and drags him toward the door of the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikolai heaves Kirill into a chair. Semyon is back at his novel and watches as Kirill attempts to get to his feet and then stumbles to the floor. He slumps down, now totally unconscious, breathing deeply. Nikolai smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We went to a Kurdish place. They don't even celebrate Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Semyon steps up to where Kirill is lying and stands over him for a moment. Then he kicks him hard in the guts with all his might. Nikolai is shocked, and grabs Semyon's arm. A hand laid upon him is like deadly poison. Kirill grunts and moans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision    -   9/12/06

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Papa, what did I do?    This is Merry Christmas or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Semyon kicks him hard in the guts again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he's had enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikolai steps in between Semyon and Kirill. Semyon is shocked that anyone should face him like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who... the fuck... are you to tell me enough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikolai's face hardens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're partners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikolai looks down at Kirill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's thunder, I'm lightning. He makes all the noise, I do all the damage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hired you as a driver...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Semyon bends to roughly hoist Kirill into a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...someone to stop him killing himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you got more than a driver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikolai reaches into his pocket for a business card and offers it to Semyon. As Semyon looks at the card in the candle light, he also sees the TATTOO OF AN EAGLE on Nikolai's hand. It is obvious that the tattoo means more than the card to Semyon, and he reacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I run a mini-cab business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PINK Revision    -   11/12/06

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albanians, Chechens, Russians. They deliver packages. Anything. Anywhere. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only took this job so that I could get to meet you. (in Russian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you and I could do business together. A pause.   Semyon looks at Nikolai with utter contempt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no idea what business you're talking about. Now get out. Nikolai smiles and then leaves. Semyon watches him go then peers at his drunken, sleeping son with something approaching compassion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikolai hurries   out to his car in the rain. He hears an engine splutter   and spots Anna still trying to kick-sta her motorbike.    He approaches. She's already soaked. Nikolai watches   her try to start the bike and fail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got water in it. Deadpan, Anna looks up and holds out her hand into pourin rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Water?    What makes you think that? Anna tries to start the bike again.    Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The postmen used these. In my village. When I was a boy. Russian copy of BMW flat twin. Anna tries one more time to start the bike and growls wit fury. Nikolai gently takes her shoulders and after a brie resistance Anna climbs off the bike. Nikolai sits astride it. He kicks it. It fails to start. Anna folds her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PINK Revision   -   11/12/06

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He tries again.     And again.   He climbs off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PINK Revision    -   11/12/06

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get a bus. Anna curses under her breath. Nikolai isn't sure what to make of her. She begins to chain the bike's rear wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got far to go? Anna tucks her crash helmet under her arm and prepares to set off walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just across the park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a driver. I even do limousines. Look... Nikolai opens the rear car door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Semyon found out I let one of his guests walk home in the rain, he'd fire me. And I can take care of your bike. So... Nikolai holds open the rear car door.       Rain pours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikolai is driving Anna through the rain-swept streets. The wipers beat time as they drive in silence. As Nikolai holds the steering wheel, Anna sees the intricate detail of the eagle tattoo on the back of his right hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're a midwife. Jesus. Anna smiles politely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get used to it. A pause.   Nikolai seems vaguely horrified at a memory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't faint, but it was close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision    -   9/12/06

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many have you got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikolai half shrugs.      Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, you don't know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know, I know, it's just... it makes me upset, you know? Thinking about it. This time of year. They're back in Yekaterinburg. In the forests. Near the mountains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Left here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikolai turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Semyon employs you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm... sort of freelance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said he'd fire you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikolai doesn't answer.      Anna decides she can be bold

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever meet a girl called Tatiana?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meet lots of girls called Tatiana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In that case, no, I never heard of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna doesn't care for the smile on Nikolai's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She died last night on my shift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITE Revision    -   9/12/06

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you did birth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes birth and death go together. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She had needle punctures all over both arms. Dehydration, emaciation. Early presentation of syphilis. Probably a prostitute. At the age of fourteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly, without a pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what? I hate the rain. This time of year. You ever been to Russia at Christmas? Man, snow that covers your whole house. Nikolai glances at Anna in the rear-view mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. And the ice. Whole lakes covered in ice. You don't want to walk across them, though. Ice gets thin where you least expect it.

dialogues.text: When I found out what had happened, I did what I had to do to clean the situation up. Kirill is about to speak but before he can, Nikolai speak for him.

dialogues.text: (in Russian)

dialogues.text: Passers-by stare at Anna. Helen and Stepan have come out of the restaurant to restrain her. Nikolai stops and judg the fury on Anna's face. He speaks calmly.

dialogues.text: Anger is very dangerous. It makes people do stupid things. Forget any of this ever happened. You're in the wrong place, Anna Ivanovna.

dialogues.text: I am not sure I can carry on another day. The windows won't open so I can't throw myself out. They inject me every day with heroin.

dialogues.text: He sees Semyon approaching from the kitchen and closes th diary. Semyon grabs a bottle of vodka from the bar on his way to sit opposite Nikolai. Nikolai pushes the diary across the table. Semyon pours two drinks.

dialogues.text: So why don't you go home? Semyon smiles, as if seeing Moscow through the window.
